text: I cannot forget them their names were
Aslan Alik Andre Fernanda Fred Galina
gunil Hans inorg Matti Natalia
nany sherel Usman Zara on the list is
longer for many their existence their
Humanity has been reduced to
statistics coldly recorded as security
incidents for me they were colleagues
belonging to that community of
humanitarian head workers that Tred to
bring a bit of comfort to the victims of
the wars in Cheta in the
90s they were nurses logistician shelter
expert paral legals
interpreters and for this service they
were
murdered their family torn apart and
their story largely
forgotten no one was ever sentenced for
these
crimes I cannot forget them they believe
in me somehow their memories giving me
meaning every day but they are also
hunting the dark Street of my mind as
humanitarian head workers they made the
choice to be at the side of the victim
to provide some assistance some comfort
some protection but when they needed
protection themsel it wasn't
there and you see the headlines of your
newspaper these days with the war in
Iraq or in Syria head worker abducted or
stage executed
but who were they why were they there
what motivated them how did we become so
indifferent to this
crimes this is why I'm here today with
you we need to find better ways to
remember
them we also need to explain the key
values to which they dedicated their
life we also need to demand for
justice when in 96 I was sent by the
United Nation High Commissioner for
Refugee to the north Caucasus I knew
some of the risk five colleagues had
been killed three had been seriously
injured seven had already been taken
hostage so we were careful we were using
armored vehicle decoy cars changing
patterns of traveling changing homes all
sorts of security
measures yet on a cold winter night of
January 98 he was my
turn when I enter my flat in vladikavkaz
with a guard we were surrounded by arm
men they took the guard they put him on
the floor they beat him they beat him up
in front of him tied him dragged him
away I was
uncuffed blindfolded un forced to kneel
the silencer of a gun press against my
neck when it happens to you there is no
time for thinking no time for pray
bra my brain went on automatic rewinding
quickly the life I just left
behind it took me long minutes to figure
out that those mask men there were not
there to kill me but that someone
somewhere had ordered my
kidnapping then a process of
dehumanization started that day I was no
more than just a commodity
I normally don't talk about this but I'd
like to share a bit with you some of
those 3177 days of
captivity I was kept in an underground
Cellar total darkness for 23 hours and
45 minutes every day and then the guards
would come normally twoo they would
bring a big piece of bread a bowl of
soup and a
candle that candle would burn for 15 15
minutes 15 minutes of precious
light and then they would take it away
and I return to
Darkness I was chained by a metal cable
to my bed I could do only four small
steps I always dreamed of the fifth
one and no TV no radio no newspaper no
one to talk to I had no towel no soap no
toilet paper just two metal buckets open
one for water one for
West can you imagine that mock execution
can be a Pastime for guards when they
are
sadistic or when they just bore or
drunk we are breaking my nerves very
slowly isolation and darkness are
particularly difficult to describe how
you describe
nothing there are no words for the
depths of loneliness I reach in that
very sin border between sanity and
Madness in the darkness sometime I
played on imaginary games of Checker I
would start with the black play with the
white back to the black trying to trick
the other
side I don't play chers
anymore I was told tormented by the SS
of my family on my colleague the guard
edik I didn't know what had happened to
him was trying not to think I try to
fill up my time by doing all sorts of
physical exercise on the spot I try to
pray I try all sorts of memorization
game but Darkness also creates images
and thoughts that are not normal one
part of your brain wants you to resist
to shout to
cry on the other part of the brain
orders you to shed up and just go
through
it and it's a constant internal debate
there's no one to
arbitrate once a god came to me very
aggressively and he told me today you're
going to kneel and beg for your
food I wasn't in a good mood so I
insulted him I insulted his mother I
insulted his
ancestor consequence was moderate he
threw the food into my West the day
after I came back with the same
demand he got the same
answer which had the same
consequence 4 days later the body was
full of pain I didn't know hunger hurts
so much when you have so
little so when the gods came
down I nailed
I beg for my
food submission was the only way for me
to make it to another
candle after my kidnapping I was
transferred from nortia to Cha three
days of slow travel in the trunks of
different cars and upon arrival I was
interrogated for 11 days by a guy called
russan the routine was always the same a
bit more light 45 minutes he would come
down to the Sellar he would ask the
guards to tie me on the chair or he
would turn on the music
loud and then he would yell question he
would scream he would beat me I'll spare
you the details there are many questions
I could not understand and there are
some questions I did not want to
understand the length of the
interrogation was the duration of the
tape 15 songs 45 minutes I would always
long for the last
song on one day one night in that Sellar
I don't know what it was I heard a child
crying above my head a boy maybe 2 three
years old footsteps confusion people
running so when rousan came the day be
after and before he put the first
question to me I asked him how is your
son today is he feeling better rousan
was taken by surprise R he was Furious
that the guards may have leaked some
details about his private life I kept
talking about NGO supplying medicines to
so local clinics that may help his son
to get better and we talk about
education we talk about
families he talked to me about his
children I talk to him about my
daughters and then he talk about guns
about cars about woman and I had to talk
about guns about cars and about
woman we talk until the last song on the
tape rouslan was the most brutal man I
ever
met he did not touch me anymore he did
not ask any other question I was no
longer just a
commodity two days later I was transfer
2 days after I was transferred to
another place there a guard came to me
very close it's quite
unusual and he said with a very soft
voice he
said I'd like to thank you for the
assistance your organization provided my
family when we were displaced in nearby
dagistan what could I possibly
reply it was so painful was like a blade
in the belly it took me weeks of
internal thinking to try to reconcile
the good reasons we had to assist that
family on the the Soldier of Fortune he
became he was young he was shy I never
saw his face he probably meant
well but in those 15 seconds he made me
question everything we did all the
sacrifices he made me think also how
they see us until then I had assumed
that they know why we are there on what
we are
doing one cannot assume this
well explaining why we do this is not
that easy even to our closest
relatives we are not perfect we are not
Superior we are not the world's fire
brigade we are not superheroes We Don't
Stop Wars we know that humanitarian
response are not substitute for
political solution yet we do this
because one life matters sometime that's
the only difference you make one
individual one family a small group of
individual and it matters when you have
a tsunami an earthquake or a typhoon you
see teams of Rescuers coming from all
over the world searching for survivors
for weeks why nobody question this every
life matters or every life should
matter this is the same for us when we
help refugees people displac within
their country by conflict or or
stateless
person I know many people when they are
confronted to overwhelming suffering
they feel powerless and they stop there
it's a Pity because there are so many
way people can
help we don't stop with that feeling we
try to do whatever we can to provide
some assistance some protection some
comfort we have to we can't do otherwise
it's what make us feel I don't know
simply human
that's a picture of me the day of my
release months after my release I met
the Dan French prime
minister the second thing he told me you
were totally irresponsible to go to the
north Caucasus you don't know how many
problems you've created for
us it was a short
meeting I think helping people in danger
is
responsible in that war that nobody
seriously wanted to stop and we have
many of these today bringing some
assistance to people in need on a bit of
protection was not just an act of
humanity it was making a real difference
for the people why he could not
understand
this we have a responsibility to try
you've heard about that concept
responsibility to
protect outcomes May depends on various
parameter we may may even fail but it is
worse than failing it's not even trying
when we
can well if you are made this way if you
sign up for this sort of job your life
is going to be full of joy and sadness
cuz there are lot of people we cannot
help lot of people we cannot protect lot
of people we did not save I call them my
ghost and by having witnessed their
suffering from clothes you take a bit of
that suffering
on
yourself many young humanitarian workers
go through their first experience with
lot of bitterness they thrown into
situations where they are witness but
they are powerless to bring any change
they have to learn to accept it and
gradually turn this into positive energy
it's difficult many don't
succeed but for those who do there is no
other job like this you can see the
difference you make every every
day humanitarian head workers know the
risk they are taking in Conflict areas
or in postconflict
environment yet our life our job is
becoming increasingly lifethreatening
and the sanctity of our life is
fading do you know that since the
Millennium the number of attack on
humanitarian head workers has triple
2013 broke new
records 155 colleagues killed 171
seriously wounded
abducted so many broken
life until the beginning of the Civil
War in Somalia in the late
80s humanitarian a workers were sometime
victims of what we call collateral
damages but by on large we were not the
target of this attack this has changed
look at this picture Baghdad August
2003 24 colleagues were killed gone are
the days where un blue flag or Red Cross
would automatically protect us criminal
groups and some political groups have
cross fertilized over the last 20 years
and they've created this sort of hybrids
with whom we have no way of
communicating
humanitarian principles are tested
questions and often
ignore but perhaps more importantly we
have abandoned the search for justice
there seems to be no consequence
whatsoever for attacks against
humanitarian head worker after my
release I was told not to seek for any
form of Justice he won't do any good to
you that's what I was told plus you're
going to put in danger the life of other
colleagues
it took me years to see the sentencing
of three people
Associated to my
kidnapping but this was the exception
there was no justice for any of the
humanitarian head worker kill or
abducted in cha between 95 and 99 and
it's the same all over the
world this is unacceptable this is
inexcusable attacks on humanitarian head
workers our war crime in international
law those Crim should not go unpunished
we must end this cycle of impunity we
must consider that those attacks against
humanitarian head workers are attacks
Against Humanity
itself that makes me
Furious I know I'm very lucky compared
to the refugees I work
for I don't know what it is to have seen
my old town destroy I don't know what it
is to have seen my relative shut in
front of me I don't know what it is to
lose the protection of my
country I also know that I'm very lucky
compared to other
hostages four days before my eventful
release four hostages were beheaded a
few miles away from where I was kept in
captivity why
them why am I here
today no easy answer
I was received with lot of support that
I got from my relatives from colleagues
from friends from people I didn't know
they have helped me over years to come
out of the
darkness not everyone was treated with
the same
attention how many of my colleagues
after a traumatic incident took on their
own
life I can count nine that I knew
personally how many of my colleague went
to a through a difficult divorce after a
traumatic
experience because they could not
explain anything anymore to their spouse
I've lost that
c there is a price for this type of
life in Russia all war monuments have
this beautiful inscription at the top
says
nit
ntoo no one is forgotten nothing is
forgotten I do not forget my love
colleague I cannot forget
anything I call on you to remember their
dedication and demand that humanitarian
head workers around the world be better
protected we should not let that light
of hope they have brought to be switched
off after my ordeal lot of colleague
asked me but why do you continue why did
do this sort of job why do you have to
go back to
it my answer was very simple
if I had
quit that would have meant my kidnapper
had
won they would have taken my soul on my
Humanity thank you
